title: D.C. Mayor Tackles Post-Pandemic Challenges
summary: Muriel Bowser looks to bolster police recruitment amid rising gun violence. WASHINGTON-Mayor Muriel Bowser cited the continuing surge in gun violence and the shift to working from home as challenges facing Washington, D.C., as it emerges from the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Microsoft Posts Another Quarter of Record Sales Driven by Cloud Growth
summary: Software giant saw drop in Xbox content and services revenue from the year-ago period. Microsoft Corp.'s success during the pandemic shows few signs of fading as its cloud-computing business delivered bumper sales growth to help the software giant post record revenue.

title: Glencore Probe Yields Charges Against Another Former Trader
summary: Anthony Stimler pleaded guilty to conspiring to pay millions of dollars in bribes to officials in Nigeria and elsewhere, court records show. A former Glencore PLC trader pleaded guilty Monday to what prosecutors described as a conspiracy to pay millions of dollars in bribes to officials in Nigeria and elsewhere in exchange for favorable contracts with a state-owned oil company.

title: How Students Experience Critical Race Theory
summary: Collegiate-level HR workshops bombard students with obscure neologisms, ahistorical analyses and simplistic slogans.. Editor's note: This Future View discusses critical race theory on campus. Next we'll ask, "Is a graduate degree in your field worth the cost?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Aug. 10. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Lawmakers Say Infrastructure Deal Within Reach
summary: Bipartisan Senate negotiators are working through transit funding and other issues that bogged down talks on $1 trillion package. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers expressed renewed optimism Tuesday that they were close to reaching a deal on a roughly $1 trillion infrastructure package as they worked through a series of 11th-hour holdups.

title: To Mandate or Not to Mandate Vaccines
summary: The FDA should move faster on final approval to reassure the public.. The Covid-19 Delta variant and public vaccine resistance have reignited the debate over mandates, and it may get heated. It's important to make distinctions between government and private mandates, and it would help if the Food and Drug Administration finally expedited full approval of the clearly successful mRNA vaccines.

title: First Use the Spare Covid $1 Trillion
summary: A GAO report shows how much relief cash remains unspent.. Congress has spent so much money in the past year that the recipients are having a hard time using it. That's the news from a Government Accountability Office report last week that more than $1 trillion of federal pandemic relief has yet to be spent.

title: Foreign Policy Returns to Normal, for Both Better and Worse
summary: Republicans are suddenly tougher than Democrats on Russia and China. The Trump era is truly over.. The politics of American foreign policy are reverting to their modern norms, illustrated by two recent Biden administration decisions and the attendant reactions. Donald Trump's idiosyncrasies and the Democratic opposition produced some aberrations in the traditional positions of the two major parties, confounding allies and adversaries alike. Now, Republicans and Democrats are essentially reverting to the status quo ante.

title: Laughter Can Defeat the Left
summary: They make themselves ridiculous as they try to kill comedy.. 'A transgender weightlifter and a horse walk into a bar . . ."

title: Apple's Ensemble Act Is Working Again
summary: Tech giant's iPhone dependence has shrunk, as iPad, Mac, Wearables and Services all pick up growth. It's as good a time as any to talk about Apple Inc. without the iPhone.

title: Could Larry Elder Really Replace California Gov. Gavin Newsom?
summary: The conservative radio host leads all other candidates, but a majority will have to reject the incumbent first.. Why shouldn't a conservative Republican like Larry Elder be leading the race to recall California Gov. Gavin Newsom?

title: Who Wants to Mask Up for Delta?
summary: A new variant invites a rethink of our bumpy road to Covid being a low-risk nuisance.. U.S. authorities are getting another chance at mask advice with the upwelling of the Delta variant. Will they get it right this time-by which I mean achieving not an angry social meme but giving guidance that will actually have good practical effect?

title: 'This Is Your Mind on Plants' Review: Psychoactive Sensibilities
summary: One of the most trusted authorities on what we put inside ourselves pens a trio of lively essays about opium, caffeine and mescaline.. If the chief perils of a drug include its effects on the heart and mind, then in the view of many monarchs, coffee must have been the most dangerous drug humans ever produced. The sites of its consumption nurtured historical revolutions from Paris to Cairo. Charles II of England sought to ban coffeehouses (and the highly caffeinated political squabbles therein) for "Disturbance of the Quiet and Peace of the Realm," while Frederick II hired unemployed veterans as Kaffeeschnüffler (coffee sniffers) to follow the aroma toward unpatriotic Prussians who violated the law in their preference for coffee over beer.

title: U.S., Russian Officials to Hold Talks on Future Arms Control Agenda
summary: Washington wants to address all Russian nuclear weapons; Moscow will focus on U.S. missile defenses at Wednesday meeting. The Biden administration will take its first step toward defining its future arms control agenda with Moscow when senior U.S. and Russian officials meet Wednesday for strategic stability talks in Geneva.

title: Apple Profit Sets Record on Strong iPhone Sales
summary: Device maker leads tech giants in continued streak of dominance. Apple Inc. posted the biggest spring-quarter profit in its 45-year history, leading a streak of record-setting earnings for technology companies even as the pandemic continues to weigh on the global economy.

title: Credit Suisse Expected to Publish Details of Archegos Failures
summary: Report could come as soon as Thursday, is likely to focus on bank's risk management unit, human errors in judgment and unheeded risk. Credit Suisse Group AG is likely to publish an investigation as soon as Thursday into the breakdown that led to massive losses from family office Archegos Capital Management, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Google Revenue Surges as Online Advertising Market Thrives
summary: Internet search giant's profit more than doubled in second quarter as regulatory headwinds mount. Google's parent company flexed its digital dominance, reporting its highest quarter ever for sales and profit behind a gusher of online advertising from businesses vying for customers across reopened economies.

title: Elevator Maker Otis Faces Pushback From Suppliers on Prices
summary: Company wants to lock in raw-material prices to keep a lid on costs, but suppliers are less amenable than last year, CFO says. Suppliers are pushing back on elevator maker Otis Worldwide Corp.'s efforts to lock in prices for steel and other raw materials, the company's finance chief said.

title: Biden Intends to Nominate Former Senate Aide to European Union Post
summary: Mark Gitenstein, a former ambassador to Romania, has been a confidant to Biden for four decades. WASHINGTON -- President Biden intends to nominate a longtime adviser to serve as U.S. ambassador to the European Union, the White House said Tuesday.

title: Lysol. N95 Masks. UPS. For Some Pandemic Winners, the Boom Is Over.
summary: Growth is slowing for some businesses, adding to challenges as they deal with rising costs and supply constraints. Some big companies that thrived at the height of Covid-19 are reporting slower growth, signaling that many consumers are reverting to pre-pandemic behavior.

title: Chinese Tech Stock Selloff Deepens
summary: Investors' concerns about Beijing's crackdowns put tech shares under further pressure. A selloff in Chinese technology stocks accelerated on Tuesday, as investors unnerved by China's widening crackdown on Internet companies and other industries sold down their holdings of many popular stocks.

title: Nasdaq, Tech Stocks Lead Market Lower
summary: All three major stock indexes snap a five-session winning streak. U.S. stocks slipped from records Tuesday, breaking a five-session winning streak for all three major indexes.

title: Martin Shkreli's Wu-Tang Clan Album Sold by U.S.
summary: The convicted pharmaceutical executive forfeited the one-of-a-kind record after his conviction on securities fraud. The U.S. government on Tuesday said it had sold a unique Wu-Tang Clan album previously owned by former pharmaceutical executive Martin Shkreli, who was convicted of securities fraud in 2017.

title: Capitol Police Officer Describes Fighting 'Hand to Hand, Inch by Inch' in Jan. 6 Testimony
summary: Hearing represents start of Democratic-led House committee's efforts to investigate the attack. WASHINGTON-Police officers who defended the Capitol on Jan. 6 described a harrowing, violent confrontation with rioters, in testimony at a House select committee's first public hearing Tuesday.

title: Coffee Prices Jump to Six-Year High as Brazilian Frost Threatens Crop
summary: Arabica-bean prices have leapt almost a third in July in latest instance of extreme weather sending jitters through commodity markets. The worst frost to strike Brazil's coffee-growing region in more than 25 years is set to cut a chunk out of next year's crop, sending prices of the bean to six-year highs on global markets.

title: Volatility Concerns Persist Despite Bullish Streak
summary: Surveys, fund flows and options activity this year have indicated a bullish streak among investors. The stock market has been relatively quiet lately.

title: 'King Arthur' Review: Round Table Love Triangle
summary: For all its romance, Bard SummerScape's indoor production of Ernest Chausson's rarely performed opera resembles an action movie with an underlying message: Don't let a girl into the boys' club..

title: Workplace Vaccine Mandates Aren't Widespread-Yet
summary: Some public employees and healthcare workers soon will have to show proof of vaccination, but so far most private-sector workers haven't faced such rules. Companies are encouraging their workers to get vaccinated as Covid-19 cases climb again. Yet relatively few workplaces are making shots required.

title: Senate Reaches $2 Billion Bipartisan Deal for Capitol Security
summary: Bill includes funding to expedite the resettlement of Afghans who helped U.S. troops. WASHINGTON-The Senate has reached a bipartisan deal on a $2 billion supplemental spending bill that would add funding for Capitol Police and the National Guard, security upgrades for Congress, and expedite the resettlement of Afghans who helped American troops.

title: International Icon (Wednesday Crossword, July 28)
Israel Begins Vaccinating At-Risk Children Under 12
summary: Officials say young children with certain underlying conditions should get the shot. TEL AVIV-Israel authorized the use of Pfizer Inc.'s Covid-19 vaccine for vulnerable children between five and 11 years old, as cases of the highly contagious Delta variant rise sharply.

title: Ex-Military Analyst Gets 45 Months for Leaking Drone Information
summary: Daniel Hale, who pleaded guilty earlier this year, said he gave secret government material to journalist because he wanted public to know about civilian casualties of U.S. drone program. WASHINGTON-A former intelligence analyst was sentenced Tuesday to nearly four years in prison after pleading guilty to giving classified information about the U.S. drone program to a reporter.

title: Airlines Struggle With Fuel Shortages at Some Small Western U.S. Airports
summary: 'Every gallon of jet fuel saved is helpful,' American Airlines told pilots. Airlines are grappling with shortages of jet fuel at some smaller airports in the western U.S., where a travel boom is coinciding with high demand for that fuel to fight wildfires.

title: Thinking About Adding Crypto to Your Portfolio? Read This First.
summary: Start small, ready yourself for risk, and do plenty of research. Should you join the cryptocurrency craze? If you're considering it, you aren't alone. In a recent survey of more than 500 financial advisers, nearly half said clients have asked them about investing in crypto compared with 17% in 2020. About 14% of advisers surveyed said they use or recommend it, compared with fewer than 1% last year. But there is more you need to know.

title: China to Revise Population Law to Try to Reverse Declining Births
summary: Lawmakers look to remove legal obstacles keeping couples from having more children. Lawmakers in China plan to clear remaining legal barriers to encourage couples to have more children, as the country faces another year of fewer births.

title: Hallmark Bets People Still Want to Send Paper Cards, but From Phones
summary: After shutting its e-card service, Hallmark introduced a way to send handwritten cards without going to the mailbox. Hallmark Cards Inc. has rolled out a way for people to handwrite a note and add it to a paper greeting card, without buying a stamp or going to the mailbox.

title: Wall Street Gets a Chinese Education
summary: Communist Party control always trumps the needs of investors.. The big surprise from this week's slump in Chinese company stocks is that people are claiming to be surprised. President Xi Jinping has made plain for years that he intends to bring ever greater swathes of China's private economy under the state's control. Guess what, Wall Street: He meant it.

title: Washington's Extra Trillion
summary: How about a little something for taxpayers' effort?. The aging Americans who set federal Covid policy seem poised to impose yet another scientifically dubious burden on young people who are at little or no risk from the virus. CNN reports:

title: The RV Vacation Meets Glamping as More Americans Embrace Outdoor Trips
summary: A handful of glamping retreats around the U.S. now cater to Outdoorsy's RV renters looking for a little coddling around the campfire. IN THE GROWING field of outdoor hospitality, a new collaboration is giving the often folksy #vanlife crowd a luxe way to escape. Collective Retreats, a company that's created glamping compounds in unexpected places such as Governors Island in New York Harbor, has teamed up with Outdoorsy, often referred to as the Airbnb of RV rentals.

title: McDonald's Appoints Its First Global Chief Customer Officer
summary: Company veteran Manu Steijaert will lead a newly created customer-experience team. McDonald's Corp. named company veteran Manu Steijaert as its first global chief customer officer, who will lead a new customer-experience team.

title: Biles and Osaka Lay Bare the Strains of Tokyo's Pandemic Olympics
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-For over a year, the Tokyo Olympics were reshaped by a global pandemic that changed everything about how sports are watched, played and organized. Less than a week into the Games, they are being defined by an entirely different challenge: a massive power outage among its biggest stars under pressure.

title: Vatican Tries Cardinal in Test of Pope's Transparency Drive
summary: Scandal over London real-estate purchase using pope's charitable funds led to charges against Cardinal Giovanni Becciu and nine others. VATICAN CITY-Cardinal Giovanni Becciu, once one of the most powerful men in the Vatican, went on trial Tuesday for embezzlement and other alleged crimes, as a scandal that has posed one of the biggest tests of Pope Francis's pontificate spilled out into the open.

title: It's Time to Start Requiring Covid Vaccines
summary: Too many aren't getting the shot, and the state has options to compel citizens.. On Thursday, Kay Ivey, the unimpeachably conservative governor of a deep red state, treated her Alabama constituents to some straight talk. "I want folks to get vaccinated. That's the cure," she said. "The data proves that it works." And it "doesn't cost you anything. It saves lives."

title: Covid Is the 21st Century's Sputnik
summary: The space race spawned Darpa. The pandemic proved we need an agency for health innovation.. America's leadership of business, science and culture seemed unassailable in 1957. With less than 6% of the world's population, the U.S. produced close to 40% of global economic output, according to a United Nations survey. Scientists working in the U.S. had been awarded by far the most Nobel Prizes. The U.S. had more telephones, television sets, cars and refrigerators than any other country. Students came from every nation to study at great American universities. Yet all it took to shake America's pride and confidence was some electronic beeps from hundreds of miles above earth.

title: Atlanta-Area Spa Shooter Pleads Guilty in Deal With Prosecutor
summary: Robert Aaron Long agrees to four sentences of life in prison without the possibility of parole in Cherokee County. Robert Aaron Long pleaded guilty Tuesday to four counts of murder and other charges for the first shooting in a March 16 killing spree that left eight people dead, six of them women of Asian descent.

title: Jeff Bezos Offers to Waive $2 Billion for NASA Contract
summary: Billionaire says agency should return to an original plan to have two companies provide lunar landers for its Artemis program. Jeff Bezos offered to waive up to $2 billion in fees to NASA in an effort to help his Blue Origin LLC space company become part of a lunar-lander contract that the agency awarded solely to Elon Musk's SpaceX.

title: Covid-19 Deaths Rise Sharply in Indonesia
summary: The world's fourth most populous nation, where about 7% of people are fully vaccinated, reported more than 2,000 daily fatalities for the first time. Indonesia recorded a sharp increase in daily Covid-19 deaths, reporting more than 2,000 for the first time on Tuesday, as the highly infectious Delta variant swamps the densely populated and largely unvaccinated country.

title: GE and Raytheon Aren't Yet Flying on All Engines
summary: Both conglomerates have reported a surge in airline shop visits in the second quarter, but their aerospace businesses still face many unknowns. Jet engines are roaring back to life, but shouldn't yet be declared ready for takeoff.

title: Saudi Arabia to Impose Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate
summary: Persian Gulf states take steps to bar the unvaccinated from public spaces, as the U.S. and Europe grapple with restrictions. RIYADH-Saudi Arabia is set to impose one of the world's most sweeping vaccine mandates in an attempt to combat hesitancy toward the Covid-19 shots in the kingdom, as governments globally try to confront a new surge in cases of the Delta variant.

title: China Appears to Be Building New Silos for Nuclear Missiles, Researchers Say
summary: Discovery from commercial satellite imagery follows another U.S. think-tank analysis appearing to identify a separate missile-silo project. HONG KONG-Satellite imagery appeared to show China building a new network of silos for launching nuclear missiles, a U.S. think tank said, the second such project that American analysts have accused Beijing of advancing in recent weeks.

title: A Queen of Mountain Biking Climbs All the Way Back
summary: After injuries and a victory drought, former world champion Jolanda Neff gets her biggest win ever: Olympic gold in Tokyo. Izu, Japan

title: Hong Kong Man Found Guilty in First Verdict Under China's National-Security Law
summary: A 24-year-old who collided with police officers while riding a motorcycle last year was convicted of inciting secession and terrorism. HONG KONG-The first person charged under a national-security law imposed by Beijing was found guilty of inciting secession and terrorism Tuesday in a verdict that reaffirms new limits on speech in the city and could set a precedent for future trials under the law.

title: UPS Ships Fewer Packages as Pandemic Boom Wanes
summary: Carrier says revenue jumped as higher shipping rates offset slowdown in deliveries with more shoppers venturing to stores. United Parcel Service Inc. posted a 14.5% increase in second-quarter sales despite shipping fewer packages than it did a year earlier, as higher shipping rates offset a package slowdown with more shoppers venturing to stores.

title: Intel to Move a Little Faster, Break Things
summary: Chip maker drops out of nanometer-based marketing race but still outlines aggressive-and likely expensive-catch-up plan. Intel Corp. plans to catch up to its chipmaking rival by 2024. Just don't look too closely at how it gets there.

title: So Much for Biden's 'Return to Normalcy'
summary: There is nothing normal or decent about the president's assertion that Jim Crow is back.. In "Voters See Earthquakes and Lightnin'" (op-ed, July 22), Karl Rove is right about everything except his claim that President Biden has restored "normality and decency." There is nothing normal or decent about the president's assertion that Jim Crow is back in the form of state election-law changes. There is nothing decent in his dodging the substantiated charges of influence peddling by his ne'er-do-well son. There is nothing decent about his obdurate refusal to acknowledge the effect of President Trump's warp-speed development of coronavirus vaccines.

title: 'Gossip Girl' Star Laura Benanti Felt Like She Was Born a 40-Year-Old
summary: Resume Subscription. Laura Benanti, 42, is a Tony-winning actress and singer who has appeared on TV's "Nashville" and "Younger." She stars on HBO Max's series "Gossip Girl" and co-stars in the film "Worth," due in September. She spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Age, Weight and Covid Risk
summary: The U.K. has announced it will not administer vaccines to most children under 18.. Marty Makary argues convincingly that America's reported youth Covid-19 deaths-400-likely overstates the number who died on account of Covid ("The Flimsy Evidence Behind the CDC's Push to Vaccinate Children," op-ed, July 20). Even if it doesn't, that's 400 out of around 75 million. More deadly to this cohort are the seasonal flu, fatal car accidents, suicide and drowning.

title: How My Professional Pandemic Baking Focused My Career Path
summary: Long hours in a hot bakery helped me understand what I wanted my future to be. At the start of 2020, I was offered a job as an artisan baker at New York City's beloved baked-goods mecca Levain Bakery. The opportunity was thrilling. As a college student at New York University, I would often schlep from the downtown campus to the Upper West Side for a chocolate-chip cookie and a stroll through Central Park. But it wasn't just the lure of a warm pastry that convinced me to work at the bakery. I had just left my first "professional job" after college, in food tech, and needed an income while I strategized my next career move, ideally back into something cushy and corporate. I figured a stint as a baker...

title: U.S. Moves to Assure India on Afghanistan
summary: Secretary of state visits New Delhi in Biden administration push on Asia. Secretary of State Antony Blinken is visiting India this week as the Biden administration seeks to reassure a key Asian partner over the U.S. and allied military withdrawal from Afghanistan and works to tighten security ties amid concern about Chinese influence in the region.

title: Water Protests in Iran Test Country's Leaders
summary: Unrest in Khuzestan portends new depth to challenges awaiting Ebrahim Raisi as he prepares for presidency. Weekslong Iranian protests over water scarcity present an early test for incoming president Ebrahim Raisi, who takes office next week amid mounting challenges including a grinding economic crisis and stalled nuclear negotiations with the West.

title: U.S. Home-Price Growth Rose to Record in May
summary: Case-Shiller index rose 16.6%, highest annual rate of price growth since the index began in 1987. Home-price growth climbed to a new record in May, as low mortgage interest rates continued to drive robust homebuying demand.

title: Space Travel Isn't Only for Astronauts
summary: There are always risks. But would America even exist if the ships crossing the Atlantic in the 17th century were limited to maritime professionals?. Kevin Cook states important truths about risk in pioneering endeavors ("The Case Against Space Tourism," op-ed, July 23). Undoubtedly we too often ignore these, and we should fight hard against pressure to cut corners for profit or prestige. But I find his argument that only trained professionals should be included on these endeavors shortsighted and more than a little patronizing. Would America even exist if the ships crossing the Atlantic in the 17th century were limited to maritime professionals?

title: Why Cleveland Called Its Baseball Team the Indians
summary: To honor a Native American former ballplayer.. "Cleveland Drops the Ball," writes Bert Stratton (op-ed, July 26). It has also dropped historical accuracy. Cleveland's baseball team has played under several names. After 1903 it became the Naps, so called for hall-of-famer Napoleon Lajoie. He left the team in 1914 and the Naps could hardly be named for a player on another team. Owner Charles Somers talked with local sportswriters, who offered the name Indians, in honor of former player Louis Sockalexis, a Penobscot Native American from Maine.

title: U.S. Durable-Goods Orders Advanced in June
summary: New orders rose 0.8%; gains have been recorded in 13 of the last 14 months. Orders for cars, appliances and other durable goods increased in June, signaling continued strength in the U.S. economy as manufacturers continue to deal with shortages in parts and labor and confront higher material costs.

title: Lysol Maker Sees Disinfectant Sales Slow Amid Pandemic Recovery
summary: Shares of Reckitt Benckiser fall as U.K. company faces industrywide trend of rising input costs. The maker of Lysol has ridden a wave of demand for its cleaning products since Covid-19 hit. Now Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC is grappling with a pandemic-recovery double whammy: slowing sales of disinfectants and rising cost inflation.

title: White-Tailed Deer Are Not Livestock
summary: Wildlife should not be exploited, sold or bartered for personal gain.. In "How to Solve America's Wild Deer Problem: Eat Them" (Review, July 10), Frank Hyman postulates that commercialization of white-tailed deer harvest and marketing would resolve the problem of uneven deer population distribution. Although this might seem like a silver bullet, I remain opposed to demoting game wildlife species to the status of livestock. Wildlife should not be exploited, sold or bartered for personal gain.

title: GE's Turnaround Rides a Pandemic Rebound
summary: Industrial giant raises 2021 cash flow goals on higher orders for jet engines, power and hospital equipment. General Electric Co. reported higher orders for its industrial machinery and raised its goal for cash flows this year, as the manufacturer continues to recover from pandemic-induced shocks to the global economy.

title: Live Music Is Back, but the Musicians Are Out of Practice
summary: Resume Subscription. After a long, quiet stretch, Matty Metcalfe suddenly found himself planning the most frenetic week of his 20-year career as a professional musician.

title: From Billie Eilish to BTS, the Best Songs You Should Listen to Now
summary: Here's WSJ.'s monthly roundup of new pop releases-everything that's grabbing our attention, making us think or getting us dancing.. After her pop group Fifth Harmony went on hiatus in 2018, Normani dropped her first solo single in 2019 with "Motivation" and its impressively choreographed music video. With "Wild Side," her newest single, Normani demonstrates that "Motivation's" success was not just beginner's luck. The Aaliyah-inspired track's pulsating beat makes space for Normani's falsetto.

title: 10 Books to Read: The Best Reviews of July
summary: 'An American Marriage,' 'The Ambassador,' 'The Letters of Shirley Jackson' and more of the books our reviewers highlighted this month..

title: Is Tesla the Meme Stock of Yesteryear?
summary: Just as Elon Musk's firm begins to look fundamentally more solid, investors have moved on to other speculative objects. For years, Tesla stock charged ever higher despite weak operating results. So far in 2021, that pattern has reversed itself.

title: Japan Shuts Out Team USA to Win Softball Gold
summary: The home team sealed a 2-0 victory in the sport's return to the Olympics after a 13-year absence. TOKYO-The U.S. Olympic softball team spent 13 years waiting for a rematch that had once seemed impossible.

title: What Is Happening in Cuba? The Protests Against the Communist Regime
summary: Economic crisis and Covid-19 pandemic lead to deteriorating living conditions, electricity outages and shortages of food and medicine. Cuban citizens took to the streets across the country for the first time in more than six decades to protest against deteriorating living conditions and the lack of basic goods and services, including medical attention amid increasing numbers of coronavirus infections.

title: Ad-Tech Company AdTheorent Reaches $1 Billion SPAC Deal to Go Public
summary: Firm joins others in digital-advertising sector in raising money and going public. Advertising-technology company AdTheorent Inc. is combining with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public in a deal that values the firm at about $1 billion, the companies said.

title: Tesla, Apple, Alibaba, F5 Networks: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Investors are watching for results from Apple, Microsoft and Alphabet after the close; Chinese tech stocks took another hit. U.S. stock futures ticked lower as investors awaited earnings reports from the biggest technology giants. Here's what we're watching ahead of Tuesday's open.

title: Parents Get Their Ultimate Fantasy: A Quiet House
summary: Kids are back at camp and activities this summer, while many parents are still working from home; 'This is magic'. Kelli Langton's house and life have been full since March 2020, as she juggled her two kids' schooling from home with her own full-time job.

title: Instagram Adds More Protections for Teenagers
summary: Facebook separately pledged to keep younger children off its main platform, even as it explores an alternative product for them. Facebook Inc.'s Instagram will steer teenagers toward private accounts and limit how ads are shown to them, amid rising concerns from federal lawmakers and state attorneys general about social media's effects on children's mental health.

title: Vaccination Rates Drive Global Economic Growth Prospects, IMF Says
summary: Global lender raises forecasts for advanced economies but lowers them for emerging and developing countries. The economic outlook is diverging for countries based largely on how well they are rolling out Covid-19 vaccinations, according to new forecasts released Tuesday by the International Monetary Fund.

title: After Simone Biles Withdraws, Citing Her State of Mind, U.S. Team Takes Silver
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-The U.S. women's gymnastics team's decade of dominance came to a dramatic end on Tuesday when superstar Simone Biles withdrew from the competition, saying she wasn't in the right mental place to continue, and Russian gymnasts claimed the gold medal.

title: Lysol's Owner Is in Germ Limbo
summary: Consumers' vigilance about hygiene is wearing off earlier than Reckitt expected-but not enough to boost its cold- and flu-relief brands yet. The company that owns Lysol disinfectant was an early pandemic winner. Now it is becoming an early loser as the health crisis eases.

title: This British Swimmer Caught Covid Twice. Then He Won Olympic Gold.
summary: Tom Dean tested positive for Covid-19 twice in the year before the Olympics. He still qualified for the games and became the Olympic gold medalist in the men's 200-meter freestyle.. TOKYO-After British swimmer Tom Dean dropped seconds off his time in the 200-meter freestyle to qualify for the Olympics, he revealed something even more stunning about his performance. He did it after testing positive for Covid-19 two different times.

title: Former Sen. Mike Enzi of Wyoming Dies After Bicycle Accident
summary: Republican senator was known for emphasizing compromise over confrontation to get bills passed. GILLETTE, Wyo.-Retired Sen. Mike Enzi, a Wyoming Republican known as a consensus builder in an increasingly polarized Washington, has died. He was 77 years old.

title: Commercial-Property Sales Volume Returns to Pre-Pandemic Levels
summary: Recovery has been fueled by low interest rates and optimism on fight against Covid-19. U.S. commercial real-estate sales this year have rebounded to pre-pandemic levels, fueled by historically low interest rates and the belief of many investors that the worst of Covid-19 is over.

title: PsiQuantum Raises $450 Million to Build Its Quantum Computer
summary: Palo Alto, Calif., startup says its approach of using photons as quantum bits will lead to reliable calculations without errors. Quantum computing startup PsiQuantum Corp. has landed a $450 million investment led by funds and accounts managed by BlackRock Inc., amid increased investor interest in the next-generation computing technique.

title: Work-From-Anywhere Perks Give Silicon Valley a New Edge in Talent War
summary: Resume Subscription. Online interior-design startup Havenly can't compete with Silicon Valley heavyweights when it comes to compensation, but it used to have an effective weapon in the battle for tech talent: the Rocky Mountains. The 150-person company counted on Denver's outdoorsy lifestyle to help lure people from more-expensive places.

title: Bloomingdale's Joins Smaller-Store Trend With Bloomie's Launch
summary: New store will offer fewer products, but update its selection multiple times a week. Department stores such as Nordstrom Inc. and Macy's Inc. have been experimenting with smaller locations as many of their traditional, cavernous stores have been crushed by competition from online shopping.

title: Japan's Naomi Osaka Crashes Out of the Tokyo Olympics
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-For 24 hours, Naomi Osaka's Tokyo Olympics were perfect.

title: How Olympic Surfing Is Trying to Ride the Machine Learning Wave
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-South African surfer Bianca Buitendag uses some apps and websites to gauge wind and wave conditions before she competes, but she doesn't consider surfing a high-tech sport. It's mostly about trying to gauge the weather.

title: Chinese Property Titan Teeters as Investor Confidence Fades
summary: China Evergrande Group's debt-fueled growth powered its ascent, before problems started to mount. HONG KONG-For years, China Evergrande Group rode some of the biggest trends in Chinese finance, using debt-fueled growth to capitalize on a seemingly unstoppable property boom in China.

title: Valo Health Acquires Biotech Startup, Gaining Protein Technology
summary: Purchase of Courier Therapeutics gives Valo potential cancer drug. Valo Health LLC, a drugmaker valued at about $2.8 billion that has agreed to go public by merging with a blank-check company, has acquired a biotechnology startup and diversified its pipeline.

title: U.S. Women's Soccer Team Trudges Into the Knockout Round
summary: A 0-0 draw with Australia was enough to move the world No. 1 team to the eight-team final bracket. KASHIMA, Japan-In this small steel-fabricating city about 70 miles east of Tokyo-the Youngstown, Ohio, of Japan-the superstars of U.S. women's soccer team delivered a clock-punching, get-the-job done performance to keep their Olympic hopes alive on Tuesday night.

title: iCapital Gets $4 Billion Valuation in New Funding Round
summary: Firm helps channel investor funds into private-equity investments. iCapital Network Inc. raised $440 million in a funding round that values the upstart investing platform at around $4 billion.

title: Tokyo Sets Daily Record for Covid-19 Cases as Olympics Roll On
summary: City reports more than 2,800 new coronavirus infections. TOKYO-Tokyo on Tuesday set a daily record for Covid-19 cases, reporting 2,848 new infections on the fifth day of the Summer Olympics in the Japanese capital.

title: CBRE to Buy 60% Stake in Turner & Townsend in $1.3 Billion Deal
summary: Deal between world's largest commercial-real-estate-services firm and London-based project manager targets alternative energy efforts. CBRE Group Inc. has cut a deal to make one of its largest acquisitions ever, paying roughly $1.3 billion, or £960 million, for a 60% stake in Turner & Townsend Holdings Ltd., one of the world's largest managers of infrastructure, natural-resources and real-estate construction projects.

title: 'Take the Sadness Out of Saturday Night' by Bleachers Review: Inside Jack Antonoff's Music-Loving Mind
summary: The superproducer who has collaborated with stars like Taylor Swift, Lorde and Lana Del Rey offers a new record from his own indie project that reveals his joyous passion for music..

title: Biden Administration Moves to Tilt Pay, Power Toward Workers
summary: Business groups object to the Labor Department's efforts to reshape rules governing employers. President Biden is advancing a series of regulatory changes aimed at increasing workers' pay and gaining them other benefits, moves that opponents say could burden businesses amid an uneven economic recovery.

title: Big Pharma Quietly Pushes Back on Global Tax Deal
summary: Drug companies mobilize in D.C., arguing competitiveness and agility are at stake. Big drug companies and their lobbyists have a message for Congress: Don't raise taxes on the industry that brought you fast-tracked Covid-19 vaccines.

title: Beijing Gives Tech Investors a Brutal New Tutorial
summary: The pain for Chinese internet technology firms will be long-lasting-and the crackdown isn't over yet. Anyone who bought into Chinese internet stocks hoping for a bounce following the dramatic fall from grace of ride-hailing giant Didi has been taught another painful lesson this week. Fighting the Fed, or Washington, is usually a losing game-but betting against Beijing's fast-moving, often opaque regulatory apparatus in Xi Jinping's new era of centralized control is suicidal.

title: North Korea Reopens Communications Hotline With South Korea
summary: Move by Kim Jong Un regime may signal that Pyongyang is again warming to diplomacy. SEOUL-North Korea reopened direct communication lines with South Korea, raising the prospect that the Kim Jong Un regime could be ready for engagement after a protracted period of diplomatic silence.

title: Credit Suisse Taps Goldman Executive as Chief Risk Officer
summary: Swiss bank lost billions from Archegos, while Goldman escaped unscathed. Credit Suisse Group AG hired a top executive from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. as its chief risk officer, part of an effort to get a better grip on risks after losing $5.5 billion from family investment firm Archegos Capital Management.

title: Russia Holds Military Drills Off Japan's Mainland During Tokyo Olympics
summary: Uptick in tension over long-running dispute with Japan comes as Russia's athletes compete under the name Russian Olympic Committee. TOKYO-Russia's military doesn't stand down for the Olympics.

title: Team USA Trails in the Other Tokyo Olympics Medal Table: Vaccinated Athletes
summary: The U.S. ranks 14th out of 17 major Olympic committees in vaccination rate. TOKYO-Team USA athletes' vaccination rate of 85.5% seems wildly successful by public-health standards, and far better than the overall U.S. rate of 57% of people who have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine.

title: This Olympic Shooter Has a Right to Bear Gummy Bears
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Mary Tucker's sweet tooth is insatiable. She devours gummy bears by the fistful. She inhales Pop-Tarts. She fondly recalls her Rice Krispies Treat days.

title: What Is the ROC? Russia and the Tokyo Olympics Explained
summary: The country is officially banned from the Games but the team of some 330 Russian athletes is competing under ROC's banner. Russia's epic, never-ending 2014 doping scandal has continuing consequences at the Tokyo Olympics. Russia isn't officially competing in Tokyo as a country but rather as ROC, for Russian Olympic Committee. Its flag and anthem have been banned. Bears, too, have been an issue.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Famed Track Coach Alberto Salazar Permanently Suspended by U.S. Center for SafeSport
summary: The former Nike-backed coach is also under a separate suspension for doping conduct. Alberto Salazar, the Nike -backed coach who helped revive elite American distance running but was suspended for doping offenses and sharply criticized for his coaching methods, has been declared permanently ineligible by the U.S. Center for SafeSport.

title: China Orders Tech Companies to Fix Anticompetitive, Security Issues
summary: Country continues crackdown on large technology companies with new six-month rectification program. China's main technology-sector regulator ordered the country's internet giants to fix certain anticompetitive practices and data security threats, building on a regulatory campaign to reform how China's largest tech companies operate.

title: U.S. Combat Role in Iraq to End This Year, Biden Says
summary: The president said the American military would continue to train and assist Iraqi forces in their battle against Islamic State. WASHINGTON-President Biden said the U.S. combat mission in Iraq would conclude by the end of 2021, but the U.S. military would continue to work with Iraqi forces in their fight against the Islamic State militant group.

title: Chairman of Jan. 6 Committee Casts Wide Net on Witnesses
summary: Democratic Rep. Bennie Thompson's panel will explore communications between Trump administration and lawmakers on day of Capitol riot. WASHINGTON-The House's select committee probing the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by supporters of former President Donald Trump won't hesitate to subpoena members of Congress or Mr. Trump and will try to enforce the subpoenas in court if necessary, said the panel's chairman.

title: Britney Spears Moves to Remove Father From Conservatorship
summary: Spears's new lawyer, Mathew Rosengart, filed the petition less than two weeks after he was hired. Britney Spears's new lawyer moved to have her father removed from the helm of her 13-year-old conservatorship, calling the arrangement toxic.

title: Limetree Oil Refinery Wants Bankruptcy Shield Extended to Private-Equity Backers
summary: The St. Croix refinery says environmental litigation against its current and former owners would distract from its restructuring goals. The bankrupt Limetree Bay oil refinery in the U.S. Virgin Islands asked to halt pollution lawsuits from proceeding against its current and former private-equity backers, saying it can't afford to be drawn into litigation against them.

title: New York City Says Canceling Contract With Trump Golf Course Was Justified
summary: Agreement with Trump Organization to operate Bronx golf course was terminated after the Jan. 6 Capitol attack. Lawyers for New York City argued Monday that the city's decision to end the Trump Organization's contract to operate a Bronx golf course was lawful because attracting top tournaments wasn't possible after the Capitol riot.

title: Last Victim of Miami Area Condo Collapse Is Identified, Bringing Death Toll to 98
summary: First responders spent a month combing through debris to find all those reported missing. More than a month after the collapse of the Champlain Towers South condo building in Surfside, Fla., authorities said they had identified the remains of the final victim who wasn't accounted for, bringing the total number of dead to 98.
